data.title: I can't load my package to find deprecation.
data.body:
I am getting a deprecation message on my package `view-tail-large-files` and Atom won't load my package, even in dev mode.  I see no deprecation problem.  Deprecation cop finds nothing because it won't load.

How do I solve this catch-22?

P.S.  I cleaned out all my deprecations before June so somebody slipped a new one in, which isn't quite fair.

data.title: Pinning Atom to the Windows taskbar duplicates the icon
data.body: Since 0.210.0, it appears that Atom gets two icons instead of just one if Atom is pinned to the Windows taskbar. Clicking the pinned icon will open another icon that represents the running app. I would expect the first instance of Atom to reuse the pinned icon rather than adding a new one.

data.title: Revert "Add assertion mechanism"
data.body: Reverts atom/atom#7350

data.title: Scrolling through Autocomplete breaks App's UI
data.body:
Kind of a strange bug. At first I thought my theme was at fault, but then I switched to One Dark UI and the bug was still there.

The reproduction steps are pretty easy. Open the autocomplete menu, then scroll it using the arrow keys. The entire UI will "move" up, making the top parts of the app (tabs, for example) non accesible.

Here, I made a GIF to explain myself better.

![atombug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1133339/8290257/2979bf0a-18f8-11e5-8ef9-0799115467bd.gif)

I tried searching through the issues but couldn't find a related issue (maybe my searching keywords sucked)
###### EDIT with actual information

Atom is version `0.211.0`
OS is `Mac OS X 10.10.3`

The expected behavior is for the rest of the UI not to move while scrolling an autocomplete list. The console on Dev tools doesn't print any errors.

data.title: Can't uninstall packages
data.body:
I just have a problem that when i click disable button and then click the uninstall button on the package and then I think that this package is remove because I can't see it in the package list in the setting.but it not because when i try to reinstall it by searching the package name again ,the uninstall and enable button still show on the package and i can't install it because no install button.Nothing happen when I click that uninstall or enable button.
Thx for help and sorry for my English. :(
I use Windows 8.1

data.title: can't fold code in split screen mode
data.body:
This happens every so often. Often enough to drive me crazy!

![Image of Bug](http://i.imgur.com/tdCA9tB.gif?1)

data.title: License issue with jschardet dependency
data.body:
The newest version of [jschardet](https://github.com/aadsm/jschardet) (v1.2.0) is using a "bad" license, which is being flagged as non-permissive and as such failing our `check-licenses` CI step/task.

The way I see it, we have three options;
1. Get this fixed upstream.
2. Fix the version of jschardet to v1.1.1.
3. Replace the dependency.

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: Spell correction
data.body:
_Note: This is less an issue in the common sence than an suggestion to improve the ease of use._

| Software | Version |
| --- | --- |
| Atom | 0.210.0 |
| Operating system | MS Windows 7 Enterprise |
| Google Chrome | v43.0.2357.124 m |

To use the spell correction you've to set the cursor to the word (or mark it). Simply right-clicking on the word and click on "Correct Spelling" won't open the overlay menu.

data.title: The program 'atom' received an X Window System error
data.body:
For the one who will tag this issue: Affects **Linux** version. Likely is a bug. Causes a crash.

I'm not sure where the issue is, but since it's Atom that crashes as a result, I assume I should report it here. If it turns out to be issue somewhere else, I'll take my time to report it in the appropriate place.
### Software involved
1. Firefox Developer Edition 40.0a2 (installed from [Firefox Aurora PPA](https://launchpad.net/~ubuntu-mozilla-daily/+archive/ubuntu/firefox-aurora) as `firefox`)
2. Atom 0.210.0 (installed from [Webupd8 PPA](https://launchpad.net/~webupd8team/+archive/ubuntu/atom))
3. Linux Mint 17.1 Rebecca, XFCE edition, fully updated and with XFCE 4.12

Not sure if the last one is important, I'll add others to the list or remove the point altogether if the specific Linux distro turns out to be irrelevant.
### Steps to reproduce:
1. Run Firefox and open some tabs
2. Run Atom in safe mode to isolate the issue (I used `atom --safe .` from terminal)
3. Grab one of the Firefox' tabs and drag it over the Atom's window, not releasing the mouse button

**Result**: Atom crashes, outputting the following into the terminal:

```
[10718:0622/124154:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(170)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://code.google.com/p/chromium/wiki/LinuxSUIDSandboxDevelopment for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
ATTENTION: default value of option force_s3tc_enable overridden by environment.
App load time: 288ms
[10755:0622/124154:INFO:renderer_main.cc(212)] Renderer process started
[10718:0622/124154:INFO:CONSOLE(175)] "Enabled theme 'tomorrow-night-eighties-syntax' is not installed.", source: /opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js (175)
[10718:0622/124155:INFO:CONSOLE(175)] "Enabled theme 'tomorrow-night-eighties-syntax' is not installed.", source: /opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js (175)
[10718:0622/124155:INFO:CONSOLE(175)] "Enabled theme 'tomorrow-night-eighties-syntax' is not installed.", source: /opt/atom/resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js (175)
[10718:0622/124156:INFO:CONSOLE(56)] "Window load time: 1439ms", source: file:///opt/atom/resources/app.asar/static/index.js (56)
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadAtom (invalid Atom parameter)'.
  (Details: serial 1312 error_code 5 request_code 20 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)
```

data.title: Directory::onDidChange / File::onDidChange fire twice on file save if file not empty
data.body:
``` coffee
console.log "watching"
fired = false
entry.onDidChange ->
  console.log "fire"
  unless fired
    fired = true
    console.log "real fire"
    setTimeout (->fired = false), 1000
```

Output:

```
watching
## saving empty file
fire
real fire
## saving file with content
fire
real fire
fire
```

data.title: Tree view not refreshed properly
data.body:
I often get the following display bug in the tree view, with some file names unreadable:
![screen shot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/34704/8276774/42068ae2-18f5-11e5-8025-397a7f171172.png)
Using Atom 0.210 on OSX 10.10.3.

I can reproduce it pretty reliably the following way:
- `git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/CocoaPods/CocoaPods.git`
- `atom --safe CocoaPods`
- ensure no folder is expanded. If some are, just close all of them, close the window and Atom, and reopen it with `atom --safe CocoaPods`.
- expand `lib` → `cocoapods` → `installer` → `target_installer`

And I get the screenshot I posted above. Note that it seems to depend partly on the width of the tree view and window.

data.title: Throw error for commands registered with non-function callbacks
data.body:
This fixes https://github.com/atom/command-palette/issues/42 using the approach suggested in https://github.com/atom/command-palette/issues/42#issuecomment-104730041.

Without the fix, the test added in 6521c86 expectedly fails with:

```
CommandRegistry
  ::add(selector, commandName, callback)
    it throws an error when called with an non-function callback
      TypeError: Cannot read property 'message' of null (spec/command-registry-spec.coffee:168:22)
```

With the fix added in d477377, the tests pass again.

cc @nathansobo @kevinsawicki for :eyes:

data.title: On first open of Atom cannot install any packages or updates.
data.body:
On first open, Atom was unable to download any packages or updates. 

I got this error: /Users/samanthajohn/downloads/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/apm/bin/apm ENOENT

After some hair-pulling, I closed and reopened Atom after which it worked fine. It was quite a frustrating first experience, plus I imagine this shouldn't be too hard to fix.

data.title: npm license has expired : coffeestack
data.body:
1. Download https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/download/v0.210.0/atom-windows.zip and extract it.
2. `SET PATH=C:\path\to\extracted\Atom;C:\path\to\extracted\Atom\resources\app\apm\bin;%PATH%`
3. `cd C:\path\to\any\atom\package\it\does\not\matter`
4. Run `npm install`

Results:

```
Installing modules failed
npm ERR! Windows_NT 6.1.7601
npm ERR! argv "C:\\Users\\foolbox\\poo\\Atom\\resources\\app\\apm\\bin\\\\node.e
xe" "C:\\Users\\foolbox\\poo\\Atom\\resources\\app\\apm\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\
\npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig" "C:\\Users\\foolbox\\.atom\\.apm\\.apmrc" "--userc
onfig" "C:\\Users\\foolbox\\.atom\\.apmrc" "install" "--target=0.22.0" "--arch=i
a32"
npm ERR! node v0.10.35
npm ERR! npm  v2.5.1
npm ERR! code E402

npm ERR! npm license has expired : coffeestack
npm ERR!
npm ERR! If you need help, you may report this error at:
npm ERR!     <http://github.com/npm/npm/issues>
```

I think maybe step 3, above, might only apply to packages which have dependencies to install but I haven't checked.

data.title: Searching for installed package returns nothing
data.body:
version : https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/852456fafef5ef7b6502a16f95219ed0a094809d
Steps:

- Click packages and then search for it
- Nothing returns.

Restarting atom makes it work again but after a few search on installed packages happens again.

data.title: Code snippets inside tag attributes
data.body:
It would be awesome to allow code snippet hints to work inside of <tag> attributes.

Currently mytag src = "my_code_snippet_hint_here" will not render code snippet autocomplete options inside tag attribute quotes.

This editor is amazing! Thanks!

Jon

data.title: add pane resize keyboard commands
data.body:
This PR add commands `pane:shrink` and `pane:enlarge` to make it enable resize the panes with keyboard.

The following is the keymap binding:

| Command name | Default key binding | Comment |
| --- | :-: | --- |
| `pane:enlarge` | `cmd-alt-=` | enlarge the current pane by 10% |
| `panes:shrink` | `cmd-alt--` | shrink the current pane by 10% |

Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7332

data.title: Bundle linter in the core
data.body:
Atom is a Code Editor/IDE for Developers and those developers make mistakes. A base linter provider is something that everyone needs. There was a time when `linter` API and codebase wasn't shiny enough for it to be made a part of core.

But now we have rebuilt the `linter` package from the ground and consumed the latest technologies (i.e services) to provide API to linters. It's [API](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-plus/wiki/Linter-API) and other docs can be found in the [linter-plus](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-plus) wiki. It's API is inspired from the awesome `autocomplete-plus`. The rewrite also features a completely new UI based on suggestions from the AtomLinter Org members and styles from @simurai . Furthermore it accepts anonymous objects as messages allowing the providers to write unit-tests.

It also has a UI to show errors from the current file or project. Which is very important for the Nuclide IDE and project-based languages like FlowJS, HackLang and others. and the Error Objects can contain traces that expand over the lines. It is also extremely easy to style. and It doesn't have to save a temp file to disk to lint files. It also supports `lintOnFly` and `onSave` linters.

It even exports it's self service to packages who have daemons in separate processes and want to trigger lint without waiting for a save or change in the buffer. Also in the tooltip and bottom panel are positions that user can click on and be directed to the file:line:col instead of just jumping to the next error.

All these features remove all of the known limitations of old `linter` package.
**Note:** It's also backward compatible, so all the linters using the old API will still work.

Here is how it looks like at the moment
![screenshot from 2015-06-20 19 09 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4278113/8269940/e232c69c-177f-11e5-8710-8b2acf1380fb.png)

There are a lot of packages that have re-invented the wheel and written their own error UIs. If we merge `linter` in the core, all those packages can consume a similar API and eventually reduce their code complexity.

Things to be done
- [ ] Make the code shine bright (We have been working [hard](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-plus/graphs) on this one)
- [ ] Move it to the `atom` org.

Let us know what you guys think.

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of null
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]

Cannot reproduce, but maybe the stack trace is still helpful. If not, this issue can also just be closed.

I did something like:
1. Pasted some code.
2. Used `ctrl + ]` for adjusting the indention.
3. Pressed something like `ctrl + z` and `x` at the same time (by accident).

The current line was cut (so probably `ctrl+x` happend first), but using `ctrl+z` did not restore it, instead I received the error message.

Solved it by re-pasting the code and paying attention to not press too many buttons at the same time ;-)

**System**: Ubuntu 14.04.2
**Thrown From**: Atom Core

data.title: Mark Clipboard::write's metadata argument as optional
data.body:
`Clipboard::write()`'s `metadata` argument is optional, but it's currently marked as required - this updates the docs to mark it as optional.

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: Add assertion mechanism
data.body:
There are a few hard-to-reproduce uncaught exceptions lurking in Atom that are giving a subset of our users a hard time. Until now, in order to solve these kinds of mysteries, our only option other than raw luck with reproduction steps or a brilliant stroke of insight was to be more aggressive about throwing exceptions when getting into an invalid state. But, of course, we're extremely reluctant to do that because who wants to introduce an even greater chance of throwing an exception?!

This PR enables a better approach by adding a new tool to our box: `atom.assert`. This global method takes a condition, a description message, and an optional metadata callback as follows:

``` coffee
atom.assert a is b, "a is b", -> {a, b}
```

Now, whenever we have uncaught exceptions, our goal should be as follows:
- If appropriate, do something to suppress the exception. This may lead to other, weirder errors, but we also may survive without the user ever noticing. This is obviously an extremely short-term strategy, and it will need to be applied judiciously.
- Start forming hypotheses and seasoning in efficient-to-run assertions that can investigate how and where things might be going wrong. This will enable us to start chasing errors to their source as we put out releases.

An example of this approach is included in this PR, referencing #5905.

@atom/feedback Once we start doing this, it could be fairly important to know if an assertion has failed when someone is reporting a bug. We'll be reporting assertion failures to bugsnag and logging them to the console. Do we want some other indicator? My main thing is that we need to be able to insert assertions without interrupting a user's flow.

It's also worth noting that this changes the API of `atom.onDidThrowError` to yield the entire `Error` object to subscribers. It's made backward-compatible by adding the old event properties to the error object. I found no packages that use this method, so it should be pretty safe to change this.

data.title: 'Home' and 'End' keys do not function as expected on OSX
data.body:
Expected behavior in a text-editor on OSX is for the 'home' key and 'end' key to move the cursor to the first and last line of the current file, rather than having no function as is current behavior. I am guessing this is the [relevant file](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/keymaps/darwin.cson)...

Version 0.204.0 (0.204.0), OSX 10.10

data.title: fix doc for TextEditor setText
Launch time slow on Ubuntu 14.04
data.body:
I have 8 GB ram and all my apps run blazing fast, including chrome which is known these days to be laggy.
Unfortunately, launch time for Atom is really slow on Ubuntu 14.04 64 bit

data.title: Windows uninstall doesn't remove .atom folder
data.body:
Uninstalled Atom via Win7 `Programs and Features`.  It failed to remove `C:\Users\<user>\.atom`, which caused [old packages](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7270) to stay installed without warning.

Update: Manually deleted `.atom` folder after uninstalling.  Ran `AtomSetup.exe` for v0.210.0.  Installed package inside Atom.  Uninstalled Atom, `.atom` folder remained, along with the package I installed.
